py-trelliscope
  • Export API
  • Edit on GitHub

Export APIïƒ

Export utilities for static deployment and validation.

Core Functionsïƒ

Static Exportïƒ

trelliscope.export_static(display_path, output_path, viewer_version='latest', include_readme=True, overwrite=False)[source]ïƒ

Export display as standalone static website.

Creates a self-contained directory with all files needed to deploy the display to any static hosting service (GitHub Pages, Netlify, etc.).

The exported site includes: - index.html with embedded trelliscopejs viewer - Complete display directory with all assets - Optional README.md with deployment instructions

Parameters:

  • display_path (Path or str) â€“ Path to the display directory to export (e.g., â€œoutput/my_displayâ€)

  • output_path (Path or str) â€“ Where to create the exported site (e.g., â€œexport/my_siteâ€)

  • viewer_version (str, default="latest") â€“ Version of trelliscopejs-lib to use. Can be â€œlatestâ€ or specific version like â€œ2.0.0â€

  • include_readme (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, generate README.md with deployment instructions

  • overwrite (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, overwrite existing output directory. If False, raise error if output exists.

Returns:

Path to the exported site directory

Return type:

Path

Raises:

  • FileNotFoundError â€“ If display_path does not exist

  • ValueError â€“ If output_path exists and overwrite=False

  • OSError â€“ If files cannot be copied or written

Examples

>>> from trelliscope import Display, export_static
>>> import pandas as pd
>>>
>>> # Create and write display
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({'panel': ['a', 'b'], 'value': [1, 2]})
>>> display = (Display(df, name="my_display")
...     .set_panel_column('panel')
...     .write())
>>>
>>> # Export for static hosting
>>> site_dir = export_static(
...     display_path="trelliscope_output/my_display",
...     output_path="export/my_site"
... )
>>>
>>> # Result:
>>> # export/my_site/
>>> #   â”œâ”€â”€ index.html          # Viewer page
>>> #   â”œâ”€â”€ README.md           # Deployment guide
>>> #   â””â”€â”€ my_display/         # Display data
>>> #       â”œâ”€â”€ displayInfo.json
>>> #       â”œâ”€â”€ metadata.csv
>>> #       â””â”€â”€ panels/
>>>
>>> # Deploy to GitHub Pages:
>>> # 1. cd export/my_site
>>> # 2. git init && git add . && git commit -m "Initial"
>>> # 3. Push to gh-pages branch

Notes

  • The exported site loads trelliscopejs-lib from CDN (requires internet)

  • All display files (panels, metadata) are copied to output directory

  • The site is completely self-contained and portable

  • Can be deployed to any static hosting service

See also

Display.view

View display locally during development

generate_viewer_html

Generate HTML for viewer

trelliscope.export_static_from_display(display, output_path, viewer_version='latest', include_readme=True, overwrite=False, write_display=True)[source]ïƒ

Export display object directly to static site.

Convenience method that writes the display (if needed) and exports it to a static site in one step.

Parameters:

  • display (Display) â€“ Display object to export

  • output_path (Path or str) â€“ Where to create the exported site

  • viewer_version (str, default="latest") â€“ Version of trelliscopejs-lib to use

  • include_readme (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, generate README.md with deployment instructions

  • overwrite (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, overwrite existing output directory

  • write_display (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, write display first if not already written

Returns:

Path to the exported site directory

Return type:

Path

Examples

>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>> import pandas as pd
>>>
>>> # Create display
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({'panel': ['a', 'b'], 'value': [1, 2]})
>>> display = (Display(df, name="my_display")
...     .set_panel_column('panel'))
>>>
>>> # Export directly (will write display automatically)
>>> from trelliscope.export import export_static_from_display
>>> site_dir = export_static_from_display(
...     display,
...     output_path="export/my_site"
... )

Validationïƒ

trelliscope.validate_export(export_path)[source]ïƒ

Validate that an exported site has all required files.

Checks for required files and returns a validation report.

Parameters:

export_path (Path or str) â€“ Path to exported site directory

Returns:

Validation report with keys: - valid: bool, True if all checks pass - missing_files: list of missing required files - warnings: list of warnings - display_name: name of the display - panel_count: number of panel files found

Return type:

dict

Examples

>>> from trelliscope.export import validate_export
>>>
>>> report = validate_export("export/my_site")
>>> if report['valid']:
...     print("Export is valid!")
... else:
...     print(f"Missing files: {report['missing_files']}")

Examplesïƒ

Basic Exportïƒ

from trelliscope import Display, export_static

display = Display(df, name="example")
display.set_panel_column("plot")

# Export to directory
export_static(display, output_dir="deploy")

Export from Displayïƒ

from trelliscope import export_static_from_display

# Export already-written display
export_static_from_display(
    display_path="output/example",
    output_dir="deploy",
    include_viewer=True
)

Validationïƒ

from trelliscope import validate_export

# Validate export structure
is_valid, errors = validate_export("deploy/example")

if not is_valid:
    for error in errors:
        print(f"Error: {error}")

Multiple Displaysïƒ

from trelliscope import Display, export_static
from pathlib import Path

# Create multiple displays
display1 = Display(df1, name="display1", path="output")
display1.set_panel_column("plot").write()

display2 = Display(df2, name="display2", path="output")
display2.set_panel_column("plot").write()

# Export all from same directory
export_static(
    [display1, display2],
    output_dir="deploy"
)

  • Server API - Development server
